articles.headline: What ‘The Big Short’ Gets Right, and Wrong, About the Housing Bubble
articles.snippet: It’s not that no one suspected there was a bubble; it’s that few people saw its full implications, and how far the contagion might spread.
articles.abstract: It’s not that no one suspected there was a bubble; it’s that few people saw its full implications, and how far the contagion might spread.
articles.lead_paragraph: “The Big Short,” the movie version of the Michael Lewis book about a bunch of misfits who foresaw the housing and mortgage bubble a decade ago and profited handsomely from its popping, is to be released widely Wednesday.

articles.headline: As TV Ad Rates Soar, ‘Super PACs’ Pivot to Core Campaign Work
articles.snippet: The groups, conceived as a way to raise and spend unlimited amounts of money on television, are now overseeing nuts-and-bolts jobs like field operations and data collection.
articles.abstract: The groups, conceived as a way to raise and spend unlimited amounts of money on television, are now overseeing nuts-and-bolts jobs like field operations and data collection.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Soaring advertising costs in early primary states are compelling major “super PACs” to realign their tactics, de-emphasizing costly broadcast commercials in favor of the kind of nuts-and-bolts work that presidential candidates used to handle themselves.
articles.byline: By Nick Corasaniti and Matt Flegenheimer

articles.headline: F.T.C. Guidelines on Native Ads Aim to Prevent Deception
articles.snippet: The Federal Trade Commission’s new rules lay out for the first time how advertisers and publishers should deploy and label native ads.
articles.abstract: The Federal Trade Commission’s new rules lay out for the first time how advertisers and publishers should deploy and label native ads.
articles.lead_paragraph: A list for pasta lovers. An article about sleep deprivation. A web page detailing the history of cocaine traffickers.

articles.headline: An Aging Society Changes the Story on Poverty for Retirees
articles.snippet: If Social Security’s shrinking trust funds aren’t replenished, pensions of the future may not be enough to live on.
articles.abstract: If Social Security’s shrinking trust funds aren’t replenished, pensions of the future may not be enough to live on.
articles.lead_paragraph: One of the great success stories of the 20th century was the decline in poverty among the elderly. That story, however, is starting to change.

articles.headline: Bedtime Reading, Written by a Robot Just for You
articles.snippet: A mediocre gift inspired the creation of Lost My Name, a start-up that personalizes books for hundreds of thousands of young readers.
articles.abstract: A mediocre gift inspired the creation of Lost My Name, a start-up that personalizes books for hundreds of thousands of young readers.
articles.lead_paragraph: One of the best presents that Asi Sharabi ever got was a bad book.

articles.headline: Patients Fear Spike in Price of Old Drugs
articles.snippet: A showdown between two drug companies, one that gives away a treatment for a rare disease and another looking to profit from it, illustrates the growing tension over the rising prices of drugs.
articles.abstract: A showdown between two drug companies, one that gives away a treatment for a rare disease and another looking to profit from it, illustrates the growing tension over the rising prices of drugs.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fred Kellerman, a retired car salesman from Los Angeles, was bedridden with a rare neuromuscular disease when he started taking a drug in the 1990s at Duke University in North Carolina. It changed his life.

articles.headline: For Martin Shkreli and Others, ‘No Comment’ Is Not in the Script
articles.snippet: Executives charged with wrongdoing used to keep quiet and defer to their lawyers. But now they are turning to social media in a legally risky move to proclaim their innocence.
articles.abstract: Executives charged with wrongdoing used to keep quiet and defer to their lawyers. But now they are turning to social media in a legally risky move to proclaim their innocence.
articles.lead_paragraph: It used to be that money managers and entrepreneurs charged with a crime or civil securities fraud would keep their mouths shut and routinely refer any questions to their lawyers.
articles.byline: By Matthew Goldstein and Alexandra Stevenson

articles.headline: Assignment America: Little Havana
articles.snippet: The neighborhood has shaped thousands of Cuban immigrants or their children into success stories, from Marco Rubio to the rapper Pitbull. But a reporter who grew up there fears its demise.
articles.abstract: The neighborhood has shaped thousands of Cuban immigrants or their children into success stories, from Marco Rubio to the rapper Pitbull. But a reporter who grew up there fears its demise.
articles.lead_paragraph: Articles in this series are exploring changes in American politics, culture and technology, drawing on the reporting and personal experiences of New York Times journalists around the country.

articles.headline: For the New Year, Let’s Resolve to Improve Our Tech Literacy
articles.snippet: From politicians’ calls to shut down parts of the Internet to Uber’s labor troubles, the news in 2015 often highlighted a failure to grasp the effects of change.
articles.abstract: From politicians’ calls to shut down parts of the Internet to Uber’s labor troubles, the news in 2015 often highlighted a failure to grasp the effects of change.
articles.lead_paragraph: Silicon Valley luminaries are easily mocked as having a precious, narrow take on the world. People in the tech industry can’t see past themselves, critics often charge; they act as if the products they build sit at the center of everything.

articles.headline: Banks Reject New York City IDs, Leaving ‘Unbanked’ on Sidelines
articles.snippet: Some top banks — including JPMorgan Chase, Bank of America and Citigroup — will not accept the cards as a primary ID, even though federal regulators have approved their use.
articles.abstract: Some top banks — including JPMorgan Chase, Bank of America and Citigroup — will not accept the cards as a primary ID, even though federal regulators have approved their use.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nearly a year ago, Mayor Bill de Blasio proclaimed that a new municipal identification card would help thousands of New Yorkers “lead fuller lives, better lives, lives full of respect and recognition.”
articles.byline: By Michael Corkery and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: When a Unicorn Start-Up Stumbles, Its Employees Get Hurt
articles.snippet: Employees at Good Technology, once valued at $1.1 billion, found their shares made practically worthless by a sale to BlackBerry for $425 million.
articles.abstract: Employees at Good Technology, once valued at $1.1 billion, found their shares made practically worthless by a sale to BlackBerry for $425 million.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Sept. 4, employees of Good Technology, a mobile security start-up in Sunnyvale, Calif., awoke to discover that their company was being sold to BlackBerry, the mobile device and software maker.

articles.headline: Tamir Rice’s Family Clashes With Prosecutor Over Police Killing
articles.snippet: The prosecutor is releasing material favorable to the officers involved in the Cleveland boy’s death, and the family fears there is an effort to avoid indictments.
articles.abstract: The prosecutor is releasing material favorable to the officers involved in the Cleveland boy’s death, and the family fears there is an effort to avoid indictments.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Cleveland grand jury has been conducting its work in private, investigating the police shooting of a 12-year-old boy named Tamir Rice that set off protests nationwide. But a steady stream of evidence has been trickling out to the public.
articles.byline: By Richard A. Oppel Jr. and Mitch Smith
